about.description:
hiPhive is a tool for efficiently extracting high-order force
constants from atomistic simulations, most commonly density
functional theory calculations. It has been implemented in the
form of a Python library, which allows it to be readily
integrated with many first-principles codes and analysis tools
accessible in Python.
about.summary: High-order force constants for the masses

name: hiphive
raw_meta_yaml:
{% set name = "hiphive" %}
{% set version = "0.7" %}

package:
  name: {{ name|lower }}
  version: {{ version }}

source:
  url: https://pypi.io/packages/source/{{ name[0] }}/{{ name }}/{{ name }}-{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: 5c8f92ae85195d00afdece5a121dda99fad9cdd66eac1b9d28f26bdeabf167e3

build:
  number: 0
  noarch: python
  script: {{ PYTHON }} -m pip install . -vv

requirements:
  host:
    - python >=3.5
    - pip
  run:
    - python >=3.5
    - pip
    - ase
    - h5py
    - numba
    - numpy >=1.12
    - scikit-learn
    - spglib
    - sympy >=1.1

test:
  imports:
    - hiphive
  commands:
    - pip check

about:
  home: https://hiphive.materialsmodeling.org
  license: MIT
  license_family: MIT
  license_file: LICENSE
  summary: High-order force constants for the masses

  description: |
    hiPhive is a tool for efficiently extracting high-order force 
    constants from atomistic simulations, most commonly density 
    functional theory calculations. It has been implemented in the 
    form of a Python library, which allows it to be readily 
    integrated with many first-principles codes and analysis tools 
    accessible in Python.
  doc_url: https://hiphive.materialsmodeling.org
  dev_url: https://gitlab.com/materials-modeling/hiphive

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - jan-janssen
smithy_version:
No azure token. Create a token and
put it in ~/.conda-smithy/azure.token
3.7.0
